snippet: An argument that the Iowa caucus was not a real election distinguishes between the exacting standards of a professional primary and a party-run caucus, in which the votes do not even officially count.
abstract: Increasing number of voices argue that the Iowa caucus was not a real election; assert that informality of the caucus led to many errors and those in favor of the format are worried that additional problems will further undermine a traditional system that has been in declining use, as more states move to the comparative convenience and reliability of a primary.

byline.contributor: Steven Yaccino contributed reporting from Chicago.

lead_paragraph: An argument that the Iowa caucus was not a real election distinguishes between the exacting standards of a professional primary and a party-run caucus, in which the votes do not even officially count.

headline.seo: After Iowa, Reliability is Questioned in Caucus System
headline.main: A Symbol of Democracy Is Criticized as Undemocratic
headline.print_headline: A Symbol of Democracy Is Criticized as Undemocratic
